key_points: UN chief condemns the attack at Kunduz mosque in Afghanistan as 'horrific'
The attack is the third on a religious institution in Afghanistan in less than a week
More than 100 people reported killed and injured in the suicide blast inside the mosque
Secretary-General António Guterres emphasized such attacks violate human rights and international humanitarian law
Guterres calls for the perpetrators to be brought to justice and expresses condolences to the victims' families
IKSP, an extremist Islamist faction, claimed responsibility for the attack
IKSP has targeted the Shia Muslim community in the past and is opposed to the Taliban
UNAMA notes a 'disturbing pattern of violence' with recent attacks on mosques and a school
The UN Security Council condemned the attack and underscored the need to hold perpetrators accountable
Security Council members state terrorism constitutes a grave threat to international peace and security
